content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Methylamine is a weak base with the formula <math alttext="C H 3 N H 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) In the following box, complete the Lewis electron-dot diagram for a molecule of methylamine. Show all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Methylamine is a weak base with the formula <math alttext="C H 3 N H 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) In the following box, complete the Lewis electron-dot diagram for a molecule of methylamine. Show all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

The following chemical equation represents the reaction that occurs when methylamine dissolves in water to form a basic solution.

<math alttext="C H 3 N H 2 aqueous plus H 2 O liquid react to produce C H 3 N H 3 with a positive 1 charge aqueous plus O H with a negative 1 charge aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>2</mtext></mrow></msub><mtext>O(</mtext><mi>l</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) The <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="2.65 molar C H 3 N H 2 aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2</mtext><mtext>.65</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is 12.54. Determine the value of <math alttext="K sub b"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for methylamine.

A <math alttext="25.00 milliliter"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of a <math alttext="CH 3 N H 2 aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of unknown concentration is titrated with <math alttext="1.84 molar H C l aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.84</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Following is a graph that shows <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> versus the volume of <math alttext="1.84 molar H C l aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.84</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> added during the titration.

(c) If <math alttext="28.25 milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>28.25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="1.84 molar H C l aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.84</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HCl(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was required to reach the equivalence point, calculate the concentration of the <math alttext="C H 3 N H 2 aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of unknown concentration.

(d) Using the symbols in the legend above, draw particles in the following beaker to represent the relative amounts of the two species, <math alttext="C H 3 N H 2 "><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C H 3 N H 3 with a positive 1 charge "><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>N</mtext><msubsup><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math>, in the solution after the first <math alttext="5.00 milliliters "><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of titrant had been added to the <math alttext="C H 3 N H 2 aqueous "><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> solution.

(e) Explain why the titration curve shows only a small change in <math alttext="p H"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> per volume of acid added when the total amount of acid added is about <math alttext="14.0 milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>14.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Include a balanced chemical equation as part of your answer.

skill.text: 3.B: Represent chemical substances or phenomena with appropriate diagrams or models (e.g., electron configuration).
